text: class of 2013 it's been a privilege for
us to serve as your student association
co-presidents this past year to all of
our friends and family here welcome to
the home and campus we've shared for the
last two years none of us could have
made it without your support you know
when we found out we'd have an
opportunity to speak with you today we
really had one big question about this
speech what's the job to be done we
started like every good case protagonist
staring out a window as rain fell
waiting for inspiration to strike we
then went to the Dean and attempted to
negotiate for more speech time but when
we anchored with an hour he only bumped
us from five minutes to six we asked
professor Anita albear say how jay-z
would handle an opportunity like this
but we never found the last page of her
case thankfully true inspiration finally
struck we should take a page out of
professor clay Christensen's book on how
we should measure our lives and so class
of 2013 we asked how will you measure
your life as business people we're
trained to measure trained to measure
progress trained to measure results
trained to be measure what can be
stamped success and what will be labeled
failure but how does that translate to
you when you leave this place when the
measurements and the latter runs in the
rankings all get much blurrier how will
you know when you're successful how are
you know you need failed when you've
made enough money when you've spent
enough time with your children and we
measured ourselves before we got to HBS
with our gmat our GPA and job promotions
and there certainly have been a number
of quantifiable elements of our HBS
experience the number of cases the
number of job interviews the number of
stamps in our passport and the number of
likes on that last post on Instagram
but sitting here together now no longer
as the strangers we were two years ago
we know that what we experienced here is
something so much more than we could
ever measure think about the moment you
remember most from HBS maybe it's the
section mate who let his guard down
during a lead class and made a room of
90 shrink to a room of family members
maybe it was that time you got in
trouble in your entire class rallied
with t-shirts to free you what we what
we took from these moments can't be
quantified or scaled these moments
amount to a feeling a feeling about our
time here together going forward each of
us will likely make it back to campus
but we suspect the walking through the
halls of Aldridge or Spengler it won't
feel the way it does now after all a new
section will be in your classroom and
the sushi line may have moved yet again
but there are places that you will feel
our HBS you'll catch the feeling when
you're at a section mates wedding or on
a reunion trip with close friends you'll
feel it when you're surrounded by the
people that we shared this journey with
HPS is not shad Aldridge Baker or even
the lawn and you know how much Kunal and
i love the lawns HBS is an academic
experience of professional experience a
social experience and a growth
experience we studied ate interviewed
danced and lived on this one campus
together the type proximity of it all
can blur the lines between the lessons
and while we've learned quite a bit
about business these past two years
we've also learned quite a bit about
life and perhaps the takeaway is that
the metrics of business are not always
applicable to the challenges of life so
as much as today is about celebrating
the past two years today is also about
looking forward and there the metrics to
which we hold ourselves in the paths we
can take are so much more varied
during our RC here kunal and I traveled
with a group of classmates from sections
j & B to Peru Peru really is a magical
corner of the world huge mountains
covered in green towering over valleys
we hiked whitewater rafted and shared
authentic dinners and then there was the
day we hiked Machu Picchu now for those
of you who are unfamiliar HBS students
can't earn nearly anything into a
competition overtly in flag football or
section Olympics of course but in a
thousand less explicit ways to that day
on the mountain was no different for
Laura and I and we raced up we didn't
stroll or poke around we gunned for the
top and when I got to the top I realized
that's not how I wanted to climb that
mountain I hadn't appreciated the
journey I've been singularly focused on
the end result and as I looked out at
the view from the top my mind wandered
wondering what I'd missed along the way
you know a few weeks later I was in my
friend's apartment looking at pictures
from the trip and I realized I wasn't in
a lot of the group shots I'd been too
busy racing ahead I'm not sure why I ran
up to the top except it's what I thought
I should do that day in Peru nobody said
it was a race to the top of the mountain
but race we did it was a finish line it
was something we could measure but it
resulted in us missing that moment the
feeling of that experience here is the
scariest news for an audience of future
managers life is full of immeasurable
moments you can measure the success of
an IPO but you can't measure the feeling
of sharing successes with loved ones you
can count the accolades on the wall in
your office but you can't measure the
meaning behind a finger painting hanging
on the refrigerator
you can count you're late nights at the
Kong but you simply can't measure that
feeling the next morning the simple
truth is your best days will be off the
charts and your worst days can't be
fixed in Excel we don't presume to offer
a solution or life formula and we don't
yet have a measurement system figured
out for ourselves but the reality is we
will always be surrounded by high
achievers racing up some mountain and
you may think that you need to start
running to up a particular path in the
moment it can be hard to say who is
setting the pace or for even climbing a
mountain that we want to be climbing HPS
class of 2013 let's remind each other to
pause and make sure we're pointed in the
right direction let's commit to
personalized advice and support our
friends when their scales get out of
whack let's remember we are members of a
team and not the competition let's start
this new journey with the realization
that life will not be easily counted or
quantified and that's ok thank you for
the immeasurable feeling we have today a
feeling that will carry with us 20 years
from now the feeling of what it meant to
be here to live this two years together
class of 2013 best of luck take care of
each other and we hope you find your
path up a mountain thank
you
